response:
Initial tests should confirm the presence and type of peripheral neuropathy (axonal vs demyelinating) and screen for common, reversible systemic causes, while also evaluating alternative explanations for ankle oedema such as renal, hepatic, or cardiac disease and venous insufficiency.

investigations = ["Full blood count", "Urea and electrolytes", "Serum creatinine and estimated glomerular filtration rate", "Liver function tests", "Serum albumin", "HbA1c", "Fasting plasma glucose", "Thyroid function tests", "Serum vitamin B12", "Serum folate", "Serum protein electrophoresis with immunofixation", "Serum immunoglobulin levels", "Erythrocyte sedimentation rate", "C-reactive protein", "HIV serology", "Hepatitis B and C serology", "Antinuclear antibody", "Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody", "Urinalysis for protein", "Urine albumin-creatinine ratio", "Nerve conduction studies and electromyography", "Ultrasound Doppler of lower limb veins", "Echocardiogram", "Genetic testing for hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy if clinical or family history suggests"]
